journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Fracture analysis of a semi-elliptical crack in a nozzle–vessel junction under external loads

article-meta.aff: 1Fatigue and Fracture Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, IK International University, Qazvin, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Fatigue and Fracture Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak 14846, Iran. email: Karosedighiani@gmail.com

abstract.p: In many previous investigations, the mode I stress intensity factor has been usedalone to analyse and predict the life of cracked cylindrical components. In this article, three-dimensional elastic finite element method was used to analyse semi-elliptical cracks located in the stress concentration area of a nozzle–vessel junction. Stress intensity factors and T-stresses were calculated for different geometrical configurations of a semi-elliptical crack and nozzle–vessel junction under different external loading conditions. The influence of these various parameters and loading conditions on both the stress intensity factors and T-stress is discussed. Itis shown that, for many cases, the mode II stress intensity factor and T-stress are not negligible compared to the mode I stress intensity factor.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Nozzle connections subjected to internal pressure and external loads are the most common configurations in many engineering applications. Pressure vessels, piping tees, and boilers are typical examples of such applications. These connection structures are often considered as the critical configuration [1–6], and therefore, safe and economical design criteria must be used in view of structural design.

Due to the stress concentration, welding effects, and limitations of manufacturing, the heat affected zone situated next to the welding area is one of the most likely locations for initiation and growth of fatigue cracks. Therefore, it is important to define an appropriate procedure for predicting the onset of fracture in these cracked specimens. The application of fracture mechanics principles in the design of such structures along with non-destructive inspection is the common way that engineers use to deal with this problem.

A cracked body, depending on displacements of the crack surfaces, may be subjected to three modes of deformation. For mode I, the crack surfaces are pulled apart perpendicular to the plane of the crack; it is called the opening mode. In mode II, sliding mode, the two crack surfaces slide over each other in the plane of the crack. In mode III, the two crack surfaces tear apart out of plane; it is called the tearing mode.

A review of previous investigations reveals that in the study of cylindrical components, usually, the mode I stress intensity factor, KI, alone is used to characterize the magnitude of the stress field in thevicinity of a crack tip. It is also used to predict the onset of fracture. Cylindrical shell intersection structures are generally subjected to complex loadingconditions. Consequently, the cracks that are generated in the nozzle–vessel junction that often experience mixed mode loading.

In spite of practical interests, there is a limited range of studies on the fracture analysis of cracked nozzles. In most cases, these studies are confined only to problems of nozzle corner cracks, in which the cracks are located on the inside surface of the shell [1, 2, 7–9] and only for internal pressure. Although there are a few limited works on the case of cracks inthe nozzle–vessel junction, where stress concentration occurs, they are confined only to the estimation ofmode I stress intensity factor. For example, API579(API, American Petroleum Institute) [10] has presented a technique to predict the mode I stress intensity factor around a semi-elliptical surface crack in a nozzle–vessel junction, which is applicable only for thin thicknesses.

On the other hand, many researchers have shown that the stress intensity factors KI and KII together with the T-stress provide more reliable predictions for mixed mode fracture. The T-stress effects on fracture toughness, crack growth rate, and crack growth instability have been investigated by many researchers, e.g. Larsson and Carlsson [11], Rice [12], and Ayatollahi et al. [13]. The results by Bilby et al. [14] point to the relationship between T-stress and crack tip constraint. Considering the relationship between the T-stress and the fracture resistance of materials, three-parameter models for mixed mode cracks have now been well established for reliable fracture prediction in cracked components.

Many researchers considered cracks in the cylindrical bodies to have a semi-elliptical shape [15]. Lin and Smith [16] showed that cracks, undercycling loading, with any arbitrary shape become semi-elliptical after some cycles. Lin and Smith [15] showed that a semi-elliptical crack, with the centre of the ellipse placed on the surface of the cylinder, is quite appropriate to model the actual cracks.

In this article, a semi-elliptical crack was considered in a cylindrical shell intersection, where stress concentration occurs. The stress intensity factors KI, KII, and KIII and T-stresses were calculated from finite element analysis for various geometrical configurations. Different types of loadings are considered separately on the nozzle: in-plane moments Mx and My, out-plane moment Mz, shear loads Fx and Fy, and axial load Fz. Finally, the effect of mode II stress intensity factor and T-stress on the fracture ofthe cracked body are investigated.

The finite element code ABAQUS was employed todetermine the related stress intensity factors as well as T-stress for different loads. A refined mesh was introduced around the crack where high-stress gradients are anticipated. Also, singular elements, which are highly recommended for crack modelling, were used for the first ring of elements around thecrack tip. The results are compared to those calculated based on the API 579 [10].

sec.title: 2 CRACK TIP PARAMETERS
sec.p: The crack problem can be studied by assuming that the near-tip stress field of the elastic–plastic crack problem is approximated by the singular term in theelastic stress solution of Williams’ series expansion [17] (1) where σij is the stress tensor. The non-dimensional functions fij(θ), gij(θ), and hij(θ) describe the angular variation of the stress field. The parameters A1, A2, and A3 are proportional to the applied load. As r → 0, the leading term dominates and exhibits r−1/2 singularity, while the higher order terms remain a finite value or approach zero. Therefore, the first singular term of the Williams’ expansion is dominant and other terms are usually neglected. Over the recentyears, an increasing attention has been devoted to study the effect of higher order terms of Williams’ series expansion on the initiation of fracture under the predominantly linear elastic deformation. Larsson and Carlsson [11] investigated the elastic–plastic crack problem in different types of specimens using finite element method (FEM) and found that the solution for the stress state near the crack tip cannot be related to equation (1) through the mode I stress intensity factor KI alone, even when the requirements for small-scale yielding are all met. They noted that the discrepancies could beresolved if the first non-singular term of Williams’ series expansion (equation (2)) is included in the near-tip stress solution, which is (2) where T11 represents a uniform stress acting parallelto the crack plane. In the notation of Rice [12], this second term of Williams’ series expansion is denoted as the T-stress or elastic T-stress. The T-stress is dependent on the loads applied to thecracked structure, crack depth, and overall geometrical parameters. Bilby et al. [14] have shown that a two-parameter (T and KI) remote loading approach characterizes the very near-tip elastic–plastic fields of a non-hardening blunted crack better than KI alone. Wang [18], Al-Ani and Hancock [19], and Betegon and Hancock [20] performed further studies to investigate the elastic–plastic crack tip field using T in addition to the singular term and they showed that T can be used as a measure of the crack tip constraint in mode I.

Some analytical and numerical researches indicatethat T-stress can also exist in mode II problems [21–25] and ignoring its effect can introduce significant inaccuracies in predicting mode II fracture. Ayatollahi et al. [23, 24] have recently demonstrated that there are many real mode II loading conditions where significant values of T exist. Ayatollahi and Sedighiani [25] investigated the effect of T-stress on the plastic zone around the crack tip for mixed modeloading. They indicated that the stress field with a T-stress always yields a larger plastic zonethan the field without a T. Thus, ignoring the T-stress in mode II can introduce considerable inaccuracies in studying mode II brittle fracture.

sec.title: 3 FINITE ELEMENT MODELLING
sec.p:
In this article, the nozzle–vessel junction is considered as the intersection of two cylinders. The geometry and main parameters of the nozzle and the semi-elliptical crack are shown in Fig. 1. The various geometries of nozzle considered are defined by the non-dimensional ratios t/rm, rm/Rm, and t/Ts, where t is the nozzle thickness, rm the mean nozzle radius (rm = ri + t/2), Ts the shell thickness, and Rm themean shell radius (Rm = Ri + Ts/2). As shown in Fig. 1(b), the crack geometry is defined as a semi-elliptical shape such that the depth of the crack is ‘a’ and the circumferential length ‘2c’. The position of a point on the crack front is defined by the parametric angle of ellipse ϕ (Fig. 1(c)), which takes the value of 90° at the deepest point. Fig. 1
Geometry and main parameters of (a) nozzle–vessel junction; (b) semi-elliptical crack; and (c)definition of the parametric angle of ellipse ϕ

In this study, the effect of welding residual stresseswas ignored. By taking advantage of the stress intensity factor superposition principle, stress intensity factors for cracked body problems combining residual stresses and different external loadings can be calculated, by adding the stress intensity factors due to the different external loadings to the stress intensity factors due to residual stresses. Here, the crack was assumed to be on the base material present next to the weld. The distance between the crack face and shell outside face is set equal to t/5, as shown in Fig. 1(a).

The fracture analysis was conducted for various configurations of the cracks and nozzle connectionsfor a wide range of geometric parameters. Each of the models was analysed separately under external loads on the nozzle: shear loads Fx and Fy, axial load Fz, in-plane moments Mx and My, and out-plane moment Mz. The loads are applied at a rigid section far enough from the crack area so that boundary conditions have no influence on the stresses in the vicinity of the crack. For the case of shear loads, a moment opposite to the produced moment due to the shear loads was applied on the rigid body. Therefore, the loads can be assumed to be pretty similar as when the loads are applied on the crack section.

Three values of t/Rm are considered: 0.5, 0.3, and 0.1. These correspond, respectively, to three types ofcylinder: thick, average, and thin thickness. The ratios of t/Ts and rm/Rm are, respectively, set equal to 1 and 1/5. The aspect ratio a/c, takes values 1/3 and 1. Also, the ratio a/t is changed in steps of 0.2 from 0.2 to 0.8. The reason these values were chosen is to provide a complete range of data for various crack and nozzle geometry configurations.

Three major techniques are used for calculating crack tip parameters in a cracked body; analytical, experimental, and numerical methods. Analytical methods are restricted to simple geometry and loading configurations. A reliable experiment often requires extensive time, expertise, and resources, which make the experiment quite expensive. It has been proven that for complicated geometries and loading conditions, finite element technique is a fairly surefire way to pinpoint the crack tip parameters.

In this research, three-dimensional finite element models of the nozzle–vessel junction were modelled and analysed using the second-order elements (20-node bricks) in the finite element code ABAQUS. The stress intensity factors KI, KII, and KIII as well as T-stress for all finite element analyses wereextracted directly from ABAQUS which makes use of an interaction integral method to compute thestress intensity factors and T-stress for a crack under mixed mode loading [26]. Figure 2 shows the typical mesh pattern used for the nozzle–vessel junction. The singular elements with nodes at quarter-point positions, which are highly recommended for crack modelling, were used for the first ring of elements around the crack tip. In the circular partitioned region surrounding the crack tip where the contour integrals are calculated, the mesh was biased towards the crack tip. The results of this study indicated that there is no significant variation in the contour integral values calculated for successive rings of elements around the crack tip. A mesh convergence analysis was also used to decide how many elements should be used for modelling. The material was assumed to be homogeneous, isotropic with linear elastic behaviour. Young's modulus E and Poisson's ratio ν were taken as 210 GPa and 0.3, respectively. Fig. 2
The typical mesh pattern used for nozzle–vessel junction

sec.title: 3.1 Choosing crack configuration
sec.p:
In this article, different uncracked models with and without fillet were analysed to determine the location of the crack. The normalized normal component of stress to the crack face for a sample case of t/rm = 0.5 and under axial loading is shown in Fig. 3, where x0 is the distance from nozzle surface and d the remoteness of the crack from vessel (Fig. 3(d)). It is clear from this figure for model without fillet that the critical location is the intersection of the vessel and nozzle. Also, for model with fillet, the critical location is the sharp corner between the fillet and nozzle, as shownin Fig. 3(b). Figure 3(c) shows a comparison between normal stresses for models without fillet at d = 0 and d = t/5 and with fillet at d = t/5. It is clear that, at the outside surface of the nozzle, the maximum normal stress occurs for model without fillet and at d = 0. Also, the normal stress at the nozzle surface for model with fillet is higher than that of theone without fillet at d = t/5. However, with increasing x0, the maximum amount of normal stress is for the case of the model without fillet and at d = t/5. Fig. 3
Normalized normal stress to the crack face resulting from axial loading: (a) model without fillet; (b) model with fillet; (c) three sections of under consideration; and (d) nozzle–vessel geometry

Based on the ASME VIII, presence of the fillet is mandatory; therefore, it was assumed that the crack forms at the weld toe. Figure 3(c) reveals that the total amount of applied stress on the nozzle section is almost equal for two models of with and without fillet at d = t/5. It should be noted that the mode I stress intensity factor is from the normal stresses to the crack face. Therefore, it can be concluded that for extremely shallow cracks, the case of the model with fillet is somewhat more critical than the one without fillet. However, with increasing crack depths, the difference between crack tip parameters for these two models would be ignorable. A similar result was found for other types of loading and nozzle–vessel configurations.

Moreover, for members thicker than 13 mm, usinglocal machining and grinding of the toe, the stress concentration can be reduced and consequently the fatigue life of the cracked bodies increased [27]. The resulting profile should produce a smooth transition from the plate surface to the weld. Although this fact results in a plate with a thinner thickness, the stress concentration associatedwith the weld fillet is less than the original weld. Therefore, the loss of section in the weld toe is acceptable based on fatigue and fracture resistance. This fact may result in a stress field far more similar to the case of when the nozzle is modelledwithout fillet. Therefore, in this article, the effect of fillet was ignored in the modelling of the nozzle–vessel junction and the crack was assumedto be at a distance of t/5 from vessel surface (Fig. 1(a)).

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: It is often preferred to show the stress intensity factors KI, KII, and KIII as dimensionless parameters YI, YII, and YIII, called mode I, mode II and mode III geometry factors, as (3) where a is the crack depth and YI, YII, and YIII are, respectively, the mode I, mode II, and mode III geometry factors. The T-stress is also written here in a non-dimensional form (4) where YT is the normalized T-stress and σ0 the nominal stress. The nominal stress for different loadings is defined as (5) where ri and ro, are, respectively, the outside and inside radius of the nozzle.

Raju and Newman [28] analysed longitudinal cracks in pressurized cylinders. They computed mode I stress intensity factor using three-dimensional FEM and showed that, depending on loading and geometry conditions, the location of maximum stress intensity factor is located at either deepest orcorner points of the crack. Carpinteri [29] analysed semi-elliptical cracks in metallic round bars under axial loading. He showed that for different ratios of crack depth to cylinder radius, there is a ratio of crack depth to crack length for which the location of the point of maximum stress intensity factor moves from the deepest point of the crack to the corner points (the points at which crack front intersects theouter surface of the bar). Similar results were reported by Carpinteri et al. [30] on semi-elliptical cracks in pipes under cyclic bending moment.

Figure 4 shows the distribution of the crack tip parameters on the crack front as a function of theangle ϕ, for axial load, shear loads, in-plane moments, and out-plane moment. It is clear for the case of Fx, My, and Mz, at the maximum crack depth, the specimen is under only mode III portion of loading. According to the figure, by moving from the deepest point towards the surface point, the mode II stress intensity factor becomes larger and when the position of crack front is close enough to the surface point, mode II is the dominant loading condition. Also, it could be seen that the mode I stress intensity factor is negligible compared to the mode II and mode III stress intensity factors. However, for thecase of My, the mode I stress intensity factor is sensible relative to the mode I and mode II stress intensity factors. Forthese three loading cases, an inflection point at the deepest point can be found for T-stress curves at which T-stress changes sign. In addition, it can be seen from these figures that T-stress reaches a maximum at approximately ϕ = 35° and 145°. Fig. 4
Distribution of the crack tip parameters along the crack front for a specimen with a/c = 1/3, a/t = 0.2, t/rm = 0.3, rm/Rm = 1/5, and t/Ts = 1

For Fy, Fz, and Mx loadings, the maximum crack driving force occurs at the deepest crack front point (denoted by ϕ = 90°), and the specimen is under a combination of mode I and mode II loadings, as shown in Fig. 4. Although by moving from the deepest point towards the surface point, the mode III stress intensity factor would be produced, it is small and can be ignored relative to the mode I and mode II stress intensity factors. It can be seen from these figures that T-stress again reaches a maximum at approximately ϕ = 35° and 145°.

The results were plotted for 15° < ϕ < 165°. Thelinear elastic fracture mechanics is based upon the assumption of the continuity of the crack front.This assumption is no longer valid at corner points ofthe crack, where the crack front intersects the free surface of the body. This accuracy loss arises from a combination of the relative coarseness of the mesh, especially in this end region where the crack depth varies rapidly, as well as from theoretical considerations regarding the appropriateness of line spring modelling at the ends of the crack. It has been shown that the order of the stress singularity at these points depends on the material property and the intersection angle [31, 32]. Pook [31] showed that the crack tip parameters values predicted by the numerical methods at corner points are not reliable and the use of quarter-point finite elements that model the square-root singularity of stresses and strains does not produce accurate results near such points. These points are discussed in detail by Parks [33] and Parks et al. [34].

For other analyses in this research, the crack tip parameters are presented only at the maximum crack depth, which seems to be the most critical point. Figure 5 shows the mode I geometry factor YI as a function of a/t for various ratios of t/rm and a/c under different loading conditions. A comparison between results for a/c = 1/3 and a/c = 1 reveals that the value of YI is always greater for a/c = 1/3. The YI values for all six loadings decreases as the crack depthincreases. This confirms a smaller crack driving force KI for a deeper crack. When a/t is large enough, the mode I stress intensity factor will become negative for some conditions (for example for Fy loading condition and for a/c = 1, rm/Rm = 1/5, t/T = 1, and t/rm = 0.5, see Fig. 5). This indicates that the crack faces get in contact and the ratio of KI/KII drops noticeably by increasing the crack depth. This is because of the high stress concentration at outer surface of the nozzle–vessel junction. Fig. 5
The variation of mode I geometry factor YI with crack depth to nozzle thickness ratio a/t for various t/rm

To examine the validity of the present finite element results, the results for a/c = 1, rm/Rm = 1/5, and t/Ts = 1 are compared to those calculated by a method presented in API 579 [10]. The stress intensity factor solutions in the API 579 are formulated in terms of a general stress distribution (weight functions). Weight function method provides a means to infer stress intensity factors for non-uniform stress distributions. Consider a surface crackof depth, a, subjected to a normal stress σx(η) that is an arbitrary function of η, where η is orientated in the crack depth direction and is measured from free surface. The mode I stress intensity factor for this case and for the deepest point of a semi-elliptical surfacecrack (ϕ = 90°) is given by the following equation (6) where h(η, a) is the weight function. In this research, the stress distributions through the wall thickness ofthe component were calculated using the FEM.

A comparison of the results calculated by FEM andAPI 579 shows a similar trend with an approximate constant difference between the results (Fig. 5). Asshown in Fig. 5, the average difference between the results calculated based on the FEM and weight function method is about 0.23, 0.6, and 0.65 respectively for Fy, Fz, and Mx loadings. Also, the calculated mode I stress intensity factor based on the weight function method and calculated for a/t = 0.2 are approximately 15 per cent higher than those calculated in this research. This difference may be contributed to the more conservative set ofassumptions and an upper bound solution used in the API 579 to compute mode I stress intensity factor. Based on the considerable difference reported for fracture toughness of a specific material, the amount of 15 per cent can be an acceptable difference. Therefore, these results can be considered as avalidation for this study. It should be noted in many standards, like the API 579, that the effect of mode II and mode III loadings and also T-stress areignored and only the mode I stress intensity factor is used to predict the fracture behaviour of a cracked body.

Figure 6 shows the variation of mode II geometry factor YII as a function of a/t for various ratios of t/rm and a/c and for different loading conditions. As shown in Fig. 6, the mode II geometry factor YII is less sensitive to a/t, a/c, and t/rm than the mode I geometry factor. However, for loading conditions Fz and Mx, the effect of t/rm is considerable. Figures 5 and 6 also demonstrate that the mode II geometry factors in all three loading cases cannot be ignored compared to the mode I geometry factors. Moreover, in some cases, mode II is the dominating loading condition (e.g. for a specimen with a/t = 0.8, a/c = 1, and t/rm = 0.1 and under Fz loading). This implies that for evaluating the fracture resistance of such structures, the use of a mixed mode fracture criterion is inevitable. Fig. 6
The variation of mode II geometry factor YII with crack depth to nozzle thickness ratio a/t for various t/rm

Figure 7 shows the mode III geometry factor versus a/t for various ratios of t/rm and a/c and for different loading conditions. It is clear that YIII is not sensitive to a/t as YI; however, the effect of a/t for Mz loading condition is more pronounced. On the other hand,the value of YIII is significantly affected by a/c. A comparison between results for a/c = 1/3 and a/c = 1 indicates that the value of YIII is always greater for a/c = 1/3. The ratio of t/rm also has a considerable influence on the mode III geometry factor. Fig. 7
The variation of mode III geometry factor YIII with crack depth to nozzle thickness ratio a/t for various t/rm

As mentioned earlier, T-stress has an important effect on fracture toughness, crack growth rate, and crack growth instability. Therefore, one of the main objectives of this study is to determine the values of T-stress. In general, the T-stress has larger domain dependence or contour dependence than the stress intensity factors. Numerical tests suggest that the estimates from the first two rings of elements abuttingthe crack tip or crack line generally do not provide accurate results. In this article, sufficient contours extending from the crack line were chosen to determine the T-stress independent from the number of contours.

Figure 8 shows the normalized T-stress YT versus a/t for various ratios of t/rm and a/c and for different loading conditions. It is clear from this figure that a/t has a considerable effect on the YT, especially for t/rm = 0.1. Commonly, an increase in the a/t leads to anincrease in the value of YT too. Also, It could be stated that, in general, the value of YT for a/c = 1/3 is lesser than that for a/c = 1. Moreover, as shown in Fig.8, by decreasing t/rm, the value of YT increases. The effect of t/rm is more pronounced for larger values of a/t. Fig. 8
The variation of normalized T-stress YT with crack depth to nozzle thickness ratio a/t for various t/rm

It should be noted that by taking the advantages ofthe superposition principle, stress intensity factorsand T-stress for cracked structures for a combination of different external loadings can be calculated simply by adding the calculated parameters for different external loadings as follows

Although the superposition principle may be violated if there would be any kind of non-linearity in a fracture mechanics problem, there is no non-linearity for the case under consideration. Therefore, thesuperposition principle can be used correctly. Inaddition, some analyses were performed for a number of cases using a combination of all the six types of loadings. It was observed that there is no discrepancy between the calculated results and those obtained by superposition principle.

To normalize the effect of T-stress relative to the stress intensity factors KI and KII, a dimensionless parameter called the biaxiality ratio B has been suggested by Leevers and Radon [35], which can be written for mixed mode loading as (7)

This equation shows that by increasing B, the contribution of T-stress in the stress and strain fields around the crack tip increases relative to the singular terms. Smith et al. [36] have shown that mixed mode fracture is significantly affected by theT-stress for specimens having a significant value of B.

Figure 9 shows the biaxiality ratio B versus the ratioof a/t for various ratios of t/rm and a/c and for different loading conditions. It is seen from this figurethat the crack depth to nozzle ratio has a considerable influence on the biaxiality ratio parameter. A comparison between results for a/c = 1/3 and a/c = 1 shows that the value of B is also influenced considerably by a/c. Fig. 9
The variation of biaxiality ratio B with crack depth to nozzle thickness ratio a/t for various t/rm

Calculation of the crack tip parameters for the deepest point reveals that under shear load Fy, axial load Fz, and in-plane moment Mx, the value of KIII is always equal to zero and consequently, the specimen is under a combination of mode I and mode II loading. On the other hand, for shear load Fx, in-plane moment My, and out-plane moment Mz, the parameters of KI, KII, and T disappears and the specimen is subjected to pure mode III loading.

Many researchers in the field of fracture mechanics have shown an interest in studying the fracture resistance of materials under mixed mode loading. For a reliable prediction of the fracture, a suitable criterion for defining the fracture initiation angle and the onset of crack growth is a vital issue. Several criteria have been proposed for predicting the fracture initiation in cracked components under mixed mode loading [36–41].

Based on the tangential stress as a critical parameter for crack initiation, Erdogan and Sih [37] proposed a criterion called the maximum tangential stress (MTS) criterion for the fracture initiation under mixed modeloading. This criterion states that the crack growth initiates radially from the crack tip along the direction of MTS θ0. Also, the crack extension takes place when the tangential stress σθθ along θ0 and at a critical distance rc from the crack tip attains a critical value σθθc. Both rc and σθθc are assumed to be material constants. It has been shown in several papers [42, 43] that the conventional criteria which consider only thesingular terms of stress, like the MTS or the minimum strain energy density criteria, fail to provide good estimates for many experimental results.

Three-parameter fracture criteria like the generalized MTS (GMTS) criterion [36] which take into account the effects of both the singular terms and the T-stress term suggest that the initial direction of crack propagation and the mixed mode fracture toughness of a cracked specimen depend considerably on the magnitude and the sign of T-stress. According to the GMTS criterion, the direction of fracture initiation angle θ0 and the onset of mixed mode I/II brittle fracture can be determined as (8) (9)

The generalized MTS criterion is simplified to theMTS criterion when the effect of T is ignored. Smith et al. [36] showed that mixed mode fracture toughness of cracked components increases due to a negative T-stress and decreases due to a positive T-stress. They also found that a positive T increases the initial angle of crack propagation, whereas a negative one reduces the fracture initiation angle. The effects of positive or negative T-stresses on mixed mode fracture toughness are higher for materials having a larger critical distance rc. Although, there is no experimental result for the specific case of crack in the nozzle–vessel junction, many other experimental works have been performed which reveal that KII and T-stress have significant effects on the fracture behaviour and fatigue crack propagation rate of different materials [44–46].

As shown in Fig. 5, the mode I stress intensity factor generally decreases for higher crack depths. Also, when a/t is large enough, the normalized KI becomes negative for some loading conditions. Meanwhile, itwas found that the mode II geometry factors cannot be ignored compared to the mode I geometry factors, and in some cases, the mode II loading is thedominating loading condition. At the present time, using the generalized MTS criterion, the effect of T-stress on the fracture initiation of the nozzle–vessel junction is studied. Figure 10(a) shows the fracture initiation angles versus the ratio a/t obtainedfrom the MTS and GMTS criteria for rc = 0.0005, 0.001, 0.003, and 0.005 and for a specific nozzle–vessel junction (i.e. Mx, a/c = 1, rm/Rm = 1/5, and t/Ts = 1). The variation of the normalized effectivestress intensity factor Keff/KIC versus the ratio a/t is also shown in Fig. 10(b) (where Keff=KI 2+KII 2). It is obvious that fracture initiation angle increases forpositive values of T while it decreases for negative values. It is also clear that the fracture toughness decreases with increase in a/t (larger values of positive T). Moreover, in a/t = 0.8, where mode II is the dominating loading condition, the T-stress has a significant influence on fracture toughness. It is obvious that as rc increases, the effect of T-stress is more pronounced. A comparison between the results reveals that by ignoring the effect of T, the mixed mode fracture resistance of the material is overestimated. Similar results were found for other specimens, but for the sake of brevity are not discussed here. Fig. 10
(a) The variation of crack initiation angle, θ0, versus the ratio of a/t; (b) the variation of normalized effective stress intensity factor, Keff, versus the ratio of a/t

list-item.p: In this article, nozzle–vessel junctions as one of themost likely locations for initiation and growth of fatigue cracks were investigated. The crack tip parameters KI, KII, KIII, and T were calculated for different geometrical configurations of crack and nozzle. It was shown that for axial load Fz, shear load Fy, and in-plane moment Mx, the nozzle–vessel junction, at the deepest point of the crack, is under a combination of mode I and mode II loading, while for shear load Fx, in-plane moment My, and out-plane moment, Mz the specimen is subjected to pure mode III loading.
It was found that the crack tip parameters are influenced considerably by the nozzle geometry, crack configuration, and loading condition.

It was shown that the mode II stress intensity factor is not negligible compared to the mode I stress intensity factor. Therefore, for analysing the fatigue life or the fracture load of such crackedstructures, appropriate mixed mode crack growth criteria should be employed together with the curves derived in this research for stress intensity factors.

It was found that the value of T-stress is significant, especially for specimens with thin nozzle thickness. Therefore, ignoring T will lead to overestimation of the fracture resistance of the material.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: polar coordinates at the crack tip
